text: Sampled from the tap at City Works. Pours amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges and laces. Aroma has a decent amount of ginger with some flora and sweet grains supporting. Flavor combines ginger and light fruits with some sweet grains and a bit of flora supporting.

Keg @ City Works, Minneapolis. Deep reddish brown pour with a small head. Nose is quite spicy. Loads of anise, dark red fruits. Worcestershire sauce. Flavor is spicy. More anise. Belgian yeast. Dark fruits. Baked apple. Umami. Full body. A touch boozy. Nice in small
Doses.
From a 75 cl bottle. Pours a clear mahogany with an ecru head. Aroma of dried fruits. Flavors of caramel and gingerbread spice. Rich mouthfeel. Smooth finish,

750 ml bottle from Johns. Always a pleasure to try a new Unibroue beer. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a large beige head. A big spicy yeasty nose. The flavor is raisin, plum, some heat, big sugary malts, fluffy palate. Very good. Unibroue has essentially created its own style with these dark Belgian style spicy beers. Of course they are inspired by many Belgian beers, but that yeast profile is pretty unique.

En fût. Pinte dégustée au Pub Deuxparquatre (Rouyn-Noranda, QC) au coût de 9,00$. Arôme: Légère odeur dépices et de raisins. Apparence: La couleur est brune-noirâtre avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dépices et de raisins avec une pointe de vanille. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de vanille en arrière goût. (Rating #7559)

Cork is blown out and ricochets off the ceiling, pours a one finger cream head that fades quickly to a ring leaving some lace. Cloudy brown/amber color. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Spicy nose and flavor is spicy with dark fruit. $8.99 for a 750ml bottle from Chase Street Market Plymouth, NH.

Poured from 750ml bottle after cellaring for 7 months. 

Cloudy dark brown with a 4-finger khaki head and very good lacing. A fine sediment appears to be suspended. 

Aroma of raisins, dark fruit, birch beer, figs, caramel, toffee, plums, several spices and much more. 

Taste of raisins, toffee, plums, cloves, licorice, allspice, nutmeg, cinnamon, dark fruit and endless layers of complexity. 

Medium/full body and medium/high carbonation with a rich, silky mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thick cloudy dark brown purple color. Decent head and lace, creamy and brownish. Flavors of raisins, dark fruits, prunes, dark grains, cherries, ginger, nutmeg, banana yeast, herbal spices. Very dense sugars, barleywine style, with bitter festive spices. The body is lean with a soft crisp, moderate thickness, good smoothness. Strong finish of ginger bread with thick bitter ester fruits, with dense spiciness. Quite robust, dry and vinous. Not too leathery, slight earth feel. Aged for a year, you get a soft bourbon like sensation of cheese. Appetizer like strength, highly sweet. Deeply warming, decent freshness while lacking a little of it. Very tasty with solid balance in the flavors, although overly acidic and coarse. Overall high quality craft, feels like a Belgian / barley wine crossover. Lost my notes on this one, so this is just what I remember, should drink it again at another new year eve.

Its a good beer, but not great. Pour dark brown-black and smells sweet- like malty, smoothy, thick cream soda or birch beer. You can taste the alcohol, along with some spicy caramel and toffee. Definitely makes sense as a beer for cold weather / the holidays, but a bit much for drinking regularly. Nice for a snowday on Pi day, eating pizza and listening to the Best Show with your booboo.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours black with a off white head. Taste Belgian yeast, caramel, dark fruit. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

DATE: December 31, 2016... OCCASION: after sharing the evening with the Morgans, we prepare for the ball to drop at home--a half hour to go... GLASSWARE: Affligem chalice... a frothy, thick quarter-finger head caps a velvet-black body... the head laces as needed... immediately spicy, with pepper, anise, fig and citrus--also some spruce tips in there... the roasted caramel is also tangible... the first sip is arresting in its warmth, medium to full-bodied and vibrant enough to engage... dry on the whole... a lasting aftertaste that resembles a rum-like burn... plum, roasted caramel, candied sugars, molasses, pepper, light maltiness, pineapple, pear and more plum... a dessert in a bottle that works quite well as a celebratory, this offering may not resonate immediately as other Unibroue beers, but its spruciness is a welcome change from other dark strong ales... where is the 10% ABV? so sneaky and subtle, but by bottles end, it catches up!

Taste: spiced fruit cake apricot and plums, bready, complex. Semi sweet, stone fruit malty raisins in the nose. Dark Brown, semi unfiltered due to yeast at bottom of bottle. Medium body. Refined, complex with a champagne mouth-feel.
Sweet Belgian ale with some oak finish. A little smoke. Great palate with booze warmth. Decent
Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle poured into a snifter. Clear medium brown with small beige head. Aroma is spice, medium body, medium carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is allspice.
Tap. Pours chestnut, large tan head, long lasting, good lacing. Aroma is pretty much potpourri. Flavor is holy hell, mega spice clove, allspice, cinnamon, nutmeg, some toffee. Medium body. Come on.

Deep dark brown, basically black, under a generous rocky light beige head. Herbal Belgian nose with a nice Trappist funk and bright stone fruit, and a mellow date and grassy undertone. Bright herbal and dark malty flavor thats got some sage and light spice mixed with loads of stone fruit and Belgian ester tone. Quite herbal in a way I cant put my finger on. But lovely and complex.

Pour is a dark brown to an almost black with a large tan head. Aroma is Unibroue yeast with some dark sugar, molasses and gingerbread spice. Flavor is sweet at first then comes a bitter cherry and dark fruit followed by the spice and a roasted chocolate malt. Alcohol is felt but not an astringent way just more of a warming. This was quite flavorful. Each sip is something different. At first I got more of a cherry cordial but after it warms i get more of a spiced porter.

750 ml bottle from Woodmans in Rockford, IL, served at cellar temperature in a Maudite snifter. Dark root beer in complexion, the smooth creamy off-white head fills more than half the glass, decaying slowly and leaving much residue...nose is dominated by licorice root, with a bit of green tea offered, and some light toasted malts...spicy-sweet on the tongue, that root beer notation is not out of place when discussing the flavor here, at least if youve had some "real" root beers made from whole spices, its got an herbal/woody character running throughout, very sweet initially but with a noticeable fruity tartness coming on towards the finish and strong caramelized malts - I can only think thyme and fennel infusing caramel-wrapped tart blueberries, I know this might be a stretch, but there is a great deal going on here...as usual with this brewery, strongly tingly carbonation and a soft, supple mouthfeel. Sapporo hasnt killed this brewerys creativity or quality yet, thank the beer gods.

Bottle. Pours a dark grape red colour with brown head. Notes of liquorice, fig, grape, malt and hop. A really surprising beer that only impressed as it went. I guess its my favourite "vegetable" beer.
Dark brown colour with cream-colored head. Aroma is fruity and a bit metallic. Taste sweet dark fruit and spicy.

Trevligt kryddig, söt maltdoft med aning köttiga toner och av bränt socker.
Tämligen trist mörkbrun färg men ett riktigt bra, tätt skum.
Smaken följer upp i samma spår men med en lite kantig, rostad karaktär. Här finns även choklad och torkad mörk frukt. 
Trevlig småspritsig kolsyra som balanserar sötman i brist på beska. Halvfyllig kropp och mjuk känsla. I eftersmaken, efter en torr avrundning, böljar en värmande alkohol upp parat med en svag beska.

[Jan 9 2016] Big bottle from Bethesda Food and Beverage. Nice dark brown body with medium head. Nose is sweet, spicy, toasty. Taste of malts, caramel, dark fruits, spices. Smooth mouthfeel. Enjoyable.

Torpedo bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with medium head. Aroma is gingerbread, dark fruit, brown sugar, Belgium candy. Medium body. Creamy texture. Slight sour fruit notes. Dark fruits and raisin notes. It's not my favorite but solid. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This corked and caged bottled brew from a beer bar poured a very small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque black brown colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was spicy and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a lingering mild vinous hop aftertaste. The ok flavor contained notes of bitter mild citrus sweet spices hops and malt. A decent one but not one that I would consider drinking again.

750 ml bottle. Nice smoking release of the cork. Murky brown pour. Voluminous off-white rocky head head, fizzes away to nothing. Spicy aroma, ginger, also dark fruit and yeasty esters.Taste follows, lovely spicy and malt affair. medium body average carbonation bit mild creaminess. Finishes quite spicy.

Aroma: Belgian yeast, caramel, spices
Appearance: hazy amber with a light beige head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, 

Tasty

On tap at World of Beer (Charlottesville, VA). Aromas of cherry cola, spearmint, some vanilla. Dark ruby with a fully lasting off-white head. Pretty dry, some spice, cherry candy, bubble gum. Medium-full bodied.

On tap at the House of Brews. Deep brown body. Big creamy off-white head. Smells very spicy. Cloves. Booze. Dark fruits and cola. Tastes sweet. Banana and clove. Dark fruits. Heavy spice, including the clove and some cinnamon. Heavy and boozy. Really nice.

Pours mahogany tinged deep brown into a snifter. Tan micro head with good retention recedes to skim surface. Dark plum, overripe pear and nut aromas. Dry with sweet dark caramel, dark pit fruit, fig, prune and stone fruit upfront turning to a warm, lasting nutty dough finish. Perfect for a rainy evening.

On tap. Pours a clear dark brown with a medium, frothy, long lasting, beige head that laces nicely. Sweet, spicy aroma of dark fruit, cinnamon and caramel malt. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, cinnamon and clove with a warming booze finish. Medium body with a smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Delicious. Has a Belgian ale quality to it.

Nose has a whiff of metallic tang but otherwise bright ginger, nutmeg, and butternut squash. Hints of chocolate. Theres toffee in the texture, a little oily on the tongue but also light. A marvelous balance between something like a tripel and a stout. Great for a chilly spring day!
Aroma is cinnamon/cardamon/spices and malts. The flavor is spices, dark malts, fruit/dark fruit and a complex mix of slight acidity, alcohol and and heat in the finish.

Draft at thirsty moose tap house. Pours brown with a half inch of khaki foam. Nice molasses and dark fruit on the nose. Rich and tender on the tongue. Lots of robust flavor and hides it's booze well. One of unibroue's better beers. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750, corked and baled. Its ridiculously interesting to find a Unibroue Ive not yet tried. So cool that theyre still making new stuff--I probably just needed to be reminded to go look for it. Pours a murky dark brown with a gigantic, surging, pillowy off-white head that rocks and rolls around in the glass until all the way after the beer is gone. Not a geyser at all, though, despite being served above cellar temp. Popped like a shot when the cork came out, though. Put that all together and youre expecting something good before the glass even settles. Nose shows big malty caramel notes along with some soft plum and red apple skin notes. Creamy medium body with surprisingly moderate carb. Mid-palate shows beautiful fruits and malts, but unfortunately lapses into an aluminum note at the finish. Bummer. Thankfully, this goes away after it off-gasses for about half an hour, so be patient with this one if that aluminum tang drives you nuts (it certainly drives me nuts). Long fruity, softly sweet finish.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium long lasting tan head. Aroma of caramel, yeast, dark fruit and winter spices. Rich flavor of dark fruit, yeast, caramel, raisins, figs, light toffee, spices and had a touch of brown sugar.

I liked thiS a bit more than their standards recently, whose flavors have somewhat melded together. The spices give it a little distinction, though I cannot adequately distinguish them myself. Still, pretty good.

Rating datant du 22 juillet 2015. Bouteille vieillie plus de 8 mois, les épices typiques dune bière de Noël ressortent en masse, lalcool marque sa présence de plus en plus quelle se réchauffe. Encore bonne malgré le vieillissement.
Tap at the Gnome. Crimson mahogany pour - deep in colo(u)r. Aroma is nutmeg and mint. Getting lots of mint on taste - almost vaporous at times - plus the spice. Cool beer.

Où, Quand, Comment : 

Bouteille, dégustée le 1/20/2015. 


Visuel :  
Couleur : brune foncée. 
Apparence : quasi-opaque. 


Arôme :  
Épices, caramel, léger malt rôti, léger de levures fruitées (petits fruits foncés), notes de houblon herbeux. 


Goût :  
En entrée de bouche : Goût assez épicé (pain dépice, notes de poivre) et de levures fruitées (petits fruits foncés sucrés).
Une dominante de caramel toffee légèrement rôti est présente avec un léger goût de sucre brun, dalcool réchauffant ainsi quavec des notes de houblon herbeux, de pain et de mélasse.


En bouche :  

Corps : moyen-rond.
Effervescence : moyenne.
Texture : légèrement crémeuse aux notes sirupeuses.
Finale : moyenne-longue, composée dun goût épicé et dalcool.

On tap at Black Bottle Brewery. Dark brown appearance with a light tan head. Aroma of spices (cinnamon, nutmeg?), Belgian yeast, dark malts and a hint of candy sugar. Similar flavor, adding mild sweetness, light bitterness and a light boozy finish over a medium body. Good.

Aroma caramel, dark fruits, 
Appearance brown, cloudy, tan foam, 
Taste medium sweetness, 
Palate medium body, full body, 
Overall a nice spiced beer that would be nice on a cold winter night. I would suggest this beer to a friend.
Bomber shared with the normal crew...good beer but be ready for spices and lots of belgian funk...maybe better with a food pairing.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with a beige head and a fruity aroma. There is a full-bodied caramel malt flavor with some strange spices and a weird fruity finish. Very unusual.

750 c&c from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours dark brown with a fizzy beige head. Aroma is spicy/fruity/malty. Med ++ body. Flavor is fruit, dark malt, clove, and something really not commonly encountered. A sort of spicy fruity finish. Im thinking its a quad. Liking it.

750 cc from Whole Foods PM. Pours turbid brown with 3-finger off-tan head. Nose is cherry, raspberry, earthy notes, some funk, yeast. Tastes fruity, with notes of cherry, raspberry, earthy, yeasty funk, and toffee. Smooth and complex flavor and well hidden alcohol.

From 750, poured into Belgian tulip glass

Aroma: strawberries, roses, floral, sweet, caramel, licorice, alcohol

Appearance: black, tan head

Taste: heavy sweet, light bitter

Palate: medium to full body, creamy texture, average carbonation

Overall: Spicy, cloves, Belgian yeasty, lots of fruits aromas. Tastes like I should have opened it when there was still snow outside. Can taste the alcohol at 10%, a tad warm. Good example of the style.

Pours dark brown with a huge light tan head. Aroma is deep with Belgian yeast, spices, cloves, etc. Taste is malty, yeasty, spicy, savory, and mimics some saltiness. Very interesting, but hard for me to find a specific flavor. Very good though. I keep getting the impression of pumpernickel bread.

On draft, pour was red brown with a nice head that laced well. Aroma of brown sugar, dark fruits, winter spices. Flavor followed, molasses mixed in, coriander and nutmeg seemingly part of the spicing. Body was moderate to thin for the style, carbonation average. An ok brew, not worth the ABV hit to the liver, though. Want more for higher content.

12oz bottle. Unfiltered stained glass deep red-brown body. Creamy, steady off-white head. Spiced aroma, sort of like an improved upon Trader Joes Vintage beer. A really mixed up beer, very yeast forward. Creamy, almost has wheat undertones. Deep, thick amber and chocolate malts, caramel. Belgian Brown Ale is more helpful "Spice/Herb/Vegetable". Pretty enjoyable overall, great mouthfeel.

750ml bottle bought at BC Signature Liquor store. Pours a dark brown with a beige head. Aroma AND taste are very complex: Belgian yeasts and spices. Flavour is extremely complex and amazingly well-rounded, with notes of toffee, gingerbread spice, and complex Belgian yeasts. Good stuff.
750 ml bottle shared with a friend for New Years 2016. Lots of spice. Spice on the nose and spice on the flavor. An interesting beer that I really enjoyed.

Pours muddy chestnut-brown with a 1-finger tan head. Malty sweet aroma, with some yeast and a wine-like note. Full body, lightly syrupy. Given the ABV, expected some booziness, but there was none to be found. Finish is long and dry. Caramel and nutty malt flavors, with a bit of a spice note. Some yeast funk at the back. The spice note becomes more pronounced as it warms.
Bottle. Pours a dArk color with a light head. Taste and smell is sweet with spice and cloves. Boozy and good for the cold days

On tap at Zax. Dark brown, slightest hints of light shine through, small creamy beige head. Winter spice dominates the aroma, and follows through in taste. Nutmeg, cinnamon, coriander, pepper, finishes with a stinging bite. Light bodied but potent.

Dark brown with reddish tint and little rimming white head; aroma is minty; flava is malty hints of chocolate with mint notes; feels medium and silky with moderate fizz; finishes malty roasty hint of alcohol

Bottle. About a year old. Pretty cool looking label. Appearance is muddy black with lots of lively white head. Aroma is clove, toffee, and gingerbread. Taste is light spice, bread, warm medium bitter finish. Not bad, just what I felt like, nice amount of spice and agree with the festive feel in the deScription, pretty mellow for a 10 plus beer.

Bottle, part of the backlog. Poured a medium to dark brown, slight haze, pretty large tan head starts off fizzy and turned creamy. Aroma of caramel, some "Christmasy" gingerbread spice, and that familiar Unibroue house yeast character. Maybe it is my imagination, but I swear it is there. And I like it. Flavors matched the nose. Spicing was kept in balance, luckily not straying into potpourri. A bit stronger than I liked, but not bad, and it was nice to have a Unibroue beer. It had been a while, which was a shame.
Sample at AK BW fest 2016. Reddish brown color. Nice big spice aroma. Taste is a nice combo of rosemary and roast.

(On tap @ Bar Hop, Jan 11 2016) Pours very dark red brown with a small whitish head and lace. Aroma of plum pudding, toffee, fruit cake and lots of spices, especially clove, nutmeg, cinnamon and allspice. Flavour is lots of raisin, prune, rum punch, loads of spicebox with clove, cinnamon and nutmeg. Fairly sweet toffee and plum pudding core. Slightly port sweet vinousness. Finish is kind of dusty house yeast and lingering spices and dried dark fruits. Medium bodied with slight alcohol heat and very little carb. The spice isnt actually totally overbearing here, making it a pretty good winter aie. It tastes like Unibroue but its kind of pleasing to see them come out with something new.
Great belgian-style ale. Sweet and caramelly with belgian sweetness and well-hidden booze:

Draught at GABBF. Pours clear dark brown with a medium, fizzy off-white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is cinnamon, spruce, brown sugar, caramel malt, earthy and woody hops. Flavor is cinnamon, spruce, caramel and cookie malt, light earthy and herbal hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

Bottle from Brewfest. Dark brown with lasting tan head and lace. Fruity tangy spicy yeasty aroma. Very fruity (but not unpleasant) raisin fig roasted caramel anise with spicy fairly dry toasty finish. Medium full body, nicely attenuated by still very rich and creamy. Excellent.

This a nice balance of a farmhouse beer with amount of funk. It looks perfect with a everlasting head, creamy. Notes of figs, dates, heavy malts no bitterness. A winner

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The aroma is fruity and complex with yeast and molasses. The appearance is brown with a nice head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is average. Overall really nice.

25.4 oz bottle. Deep purple brown with a thick cap of foam. Nose is yeast, candi, allspice, plum and wood. Whipped medium body with tiny carb prickles. Taste starts off with strong clove and cola. Hints of raisin, nutmeg, allspice and cardamom. Pretty good for a spice beer.

I dont know if Id pick this out as a spice beer--or no more than any other Belgian. This seems like straightforward quad to me. Its brown and opaque w/ an off-white head that lasts forever. Its nose is huge and fruity, lots of raisin and plum. Its full and rich on the palate w/o being too sweet w/ creamy carbonation. This is subtle, tasty and complex and very drinkable for its strength--a damn good beer.

Pour (bottle) dark brown (possible reddish) with slight head that dissappeared quickly. Semi sweet aroma on inspection. Taste is very festive. A molasses/gingerbread cookie vibe. The carb level is perfect for the flavor, with an unnoticably high ABV. I would easily make this a holiday party center piece, but personally wouldnt pick it up for casual drinking.
Draught at Le Vestiaire. Rich gingerbread all the way, caramel, figs and spicy notes, gentle warming finish. Delicious brew, specially for winter time, still a very solid brewery.

75cl bottle. Medium beige head atop cola dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, Belgian yeast, some caramel, cotton candy, alcohol. Taste is sweet, Belgian yeast, caramel, some alcohol. Effervescent medium-full body.

750mL bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma is basically what Id expect from Unibroue. Very strong house yeast esters. Pineapple and floral with some roast, caramel, and a bit of chocolate. Moderately hazy brown colored body with a medium light tan head. Starts with a bit of a sweet, spicy character. Im trying to determine if its nutmeg or all-spice. Very spicy regardless. Light musty salted caramel notes come in the middle, with a little metallic, scantly astringency later on. More yeast esters follow. Body is thin. This beer is just seems to lack cohesion.

On tap at blend. Dark brown color, small white head. Aroma is spice, fruitcake, Graham cracker, some yeast. Taste is bready, banana, orange peel, spice. Pretty nice.

Feel is thin. Low carb. A nice lighter unibroue. 10% Alcohol is well masked.

Bomber into a pint glass. Pours a dark brown, almost black. Big khaki head that persists and leaves good lacing. Aroma of figs, dark stone fruit, and spices. Taste is dark fruit with heavy spicing-nutmeg, cinnamon, etc. Quite sweet, and very tasty.

750 ml bottle. Pours an orange tinted dark brown with a resilient beige head. Aroma is fruits, roast, caramel. Flavor is milk chocolate, fruits, caramel. Finish is somewhat boozy, with some caramel and fruits. Full body, weak to average carbonation.
Draft. Dark ruby with off white head. Caramel and fruity sweetness with an abundance of spices. I find the spices to be a bit over the top. Not really my thing.

Nice, strong, spice beer. Upon opening heady aroma of toffee and malt, later that tones down to a very mild spicy malt. Flavors somewhat similar to nose with the spices seeming to have mellowed with age. Prominent carbonation gives a forward tang to the blend as well to the body. Alcohol warmth shows up in the finish. Very drinkable.

Christmas Dinner 2015 pairing with roast, yams, brussel sprouts, potatoes, and rich meat gravy. Absolute star, big notes of spices, yeasts, toffee, burnt sugar, tweels, brown sugars, malts, herbs, vegetables, and gingerbread.
Pours black with an tan head. Smells very vegetal. Tastes very licorice. Good desert sleeper.

Nice big amber head and foggy brown body in classic Unibroue fashion. Aroma of sharp cabbage, tobacco. Flavour is coriander and swamp. Vegetable to be sure but its more of a rotting stew than a symphony of flavours. I like the spiciness, some caramel on the back end. Not as great as I hoped it would be.

Pours coffee brown with a thick, almost Guinness-like fine-bubbled tan head that leaves very generous lacing. Aroma features firm roast malt, fruity, caramel and nutty notes. Scrumptious flavor presents pleasing roast malt, fruity, hard candy, caramel, nutty - and is that peppermint? - notes. Viscous body has some good fizz, leaving a sweet but not cloying finish.

Snifter at Firkin Tavern. Pours deep, opaque brown with orange around the edges.
Nose is caramel, winter spices, gingerbread. Palate has hint of banana and coriander, shifting to cherry, ginger, raisins, nuts. If Unibroue wanted to call this a barleywine instead of a strong dark ale, it would shame most U.S. efforts.
This is slightly lighter take on Grande Réserve 17, with a more explicitly seasonal profile. Joyeux Noël.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate caramel, raisin, banana, apple, coriander, and a touch of clove. It pours a dark brown with some faint orange highlights and a three finger beige head that eventually fades to a thin film outlined by a thicker ring. There are some dripping rings left on the sides of the glass with each sip. The flavor starts with a quick dose of caramel with a hint of chocolate. Stronger notes of dark fruits, raisin, and banana quickly follow. The finish has light apple, coriander, and clove. Its medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a soft mouthfeel. Overall, its been a while since Ive had anything from Unibroue. This beer makes me want to go back and revisit a lot of their beers. With all the new beers and breweries that keep popping up, its easy to forget some of the breweries that got me started in craft beer.
Why is this classified as a Spice/Herb/Vegetable?  Is there something Im missing in the deScription...and why does Ratebeer keep capitalizing the "S" in deScription even though Im not typing it that way?

Deep brown/Amber pour with a thin off white head and decent sticky lacing ... Aroma of caramel malts, gingerbread, bubblegum yeast and roasted malts with a fall spice to it..... Taste is of ginger, spices like nutmeg and allspice, bubblegum, caramel and roasted malts ... Has an herbal earthiness to it ..... Finish is spicy with caramel malts .... Has a lively mouthfeel and the abv is hidden well nice fall/winter brew

Tap at bulldog ne. Nearly black with thick frothy white head. Strong spice nose with clove and nutmeg. Initial taste is like a gingerbread cookie. Spicy. Medium high body. Some low easy flavor in the middle and then spice finish again at the end. Very interesting and quite good.

On tap at Bulldog NE for blonderedhead bday celebration. Snifter glass. Deep, murky brown. Leaning into cola color. Minimal tannish head. Pie spice aroma...is that nutmeg and ginger? Mouthfeel is full and rich. Taste combines elements of a pumpkin or gourd ale and a quad. Alcohol presence felt. Dark fruit like plum or raisins complemented well by a high dose of spices. Really well done. Tastes like a delicious and dangerous beer. Unibroue comes through again.

Dark, hazy brown pour with thin, but lasting, clingy tan head. Strange aromas and flavors abound - Smells of slightly sour cherry and dark fruit, with spices I dont typically enjoy - clove and allspice. Flavor is similar though strangely somewhat enjoyable. Mouthfeel is a little too carbonated, with a hotness from the spice despite well-hidden alcohol.
Keg at Whole Foods Short Pump. Clear dark brown, large frothy tan head, good retention. Aroma of bubblegum, yeast, caramel, chocolate. The taste is bubblegum, caramel, soy, yeast. Medium bodied.
750ml->goblet. Dark brown with big frothy tan head. Tons of spice over malt, with some citrus and dark fruit coming through in the taste. Messy. Interesting, but a fail for me.

750mL bottle. Poured very deep brown with a tall, creamy, well-retained toasted beige head. The aroma picked up sweet caramel, nutty notes, figs, and a hint of cherry topped by bready yeast and dark fruits. The flavor found dark fruits, figs, and a hint of molasses throughout.. peppery yeast and light cherry skin tartness around.. finished a touch tart with lots of rich fruits and decadent spices. Heavier-bodied with high carbonation.. great balance.. really well done!

Merci à Ju-Lo pour le partage! La bière nest pas noire, contrairement à la lecture quon ma faite de létiquette. Je vois poindre de jolis reflets rouges au travers de ce liquide sombre bien filtré qui affiche en prime, une tête blanche, uniforme et incroyablement tenace! Un nez bien épicé de Noël ou je sens une quantité importante de clou de girofle, de cardamome et de gingembre en poudre. En bouche lalcool me semble plutôt bien dissimulé et le liquide assez mince. Je nai pas limpression de déguster une bière ayant ce pourcentage dalcool. Encore une fois, le clou de girofle est très percutant. 750 ml bottle, poured into an oversized wine glass at ~50 degrees F.

Appearance: Pours a murky, impenetrable mahogany brown, and forms a massively fluffy head of ecru foam that lingers for roughly a month. Lacing is a sheet of foam along the glass, with distinct ridges marking the level of each sip.

Smell: Clove and spice, like ginger and cardamom, spring out of the aroma straightaway, atop a base of raisin and fig. Theres a bit of an earthy spice note as well, much like a white pepper, and the leaves of a juniper shrub. Beneath that, caramel and candi sweetness lurk, alongside some hints of a soft wood.

Taste: Not unlike a ginger snap dusted with some mulling spices and pepper. There is a core of sweet caramel malt, atop which layers of spice, fruit, wood, ginger, pepper, and earth are stacked, with the pepper and earth forming the thickest and outermost layers. Theres also more than a hint of alcohol heat present, especially during the finish and a bit afterward, which is slightly tempered by notes of candi sugar sweetness lingering alongside it.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied and sticky, this clings to teeth and tongue alike. Theres plenty of heat from the ABV.

Overall: If Im being honest, this is probably my least favorite Unibroue BSDA. The aspects of earth, ginger, and pepper threaten to overwhelm all the other flavor notes present, lending itself to less complexity on my palate than a Trois Pistoles, Maudite, Terrible, or 17 Grande Reserve. There also seems to have been either no attempt to disguise the ABV, or the spicy-peppery tone of this beer only serves to magnify it for me. Its a good beer, especially if one wants a Belgian Strong Dark Winter Warmer, but it misses the Unibroue mark as far as Im concerned.

750 ml bottle into signature tulip glass, best before 8/26/2018. Aromas of big raisin, plum, fig, date, light banana, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, pepper, clove, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, toasted biscuit, light roast, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast, dark/bready malt, and spice notes; with great strength. Taste of big raisin, plum, fig, date, light banana, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, pepper, clove, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, toasted biscuit, light roast, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Moderate amount of yeast spiciness and light herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, fig, date, light banana, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, pepper, clove, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/earthy yeast, dark/bready malt, and spice flavors; with a great malt/yeast spiciness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth and fairly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming lingering after the finish. Overall this is an incredible spiced Belgian strong dark ale. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/earthy yeast, dark/bready malt, and spice flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink for the big ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Dark cola colored pour with medium sized off white head. Aroma of cloves, cinnamon, nutmeg, dark ripe fruits, faint yeast, dark malts. Taste of malts, caramel, cloves, nutmeg, cinnamon, plums and faint signature unibroue yeast. Medium bodied, perfectly balanced, higher carbonation, becomes more fruity and nicely sweet as it warmed. Pretty awesome beer.

750ml bottle 
10% ABV 
Queens Quay LCBO Outlet (Torontop, Ontario, Canada)
November 29, 2014 
The beer pours a slightly hazed brownish-red with a thick creamy tan coloured cap. The aroma is dark malt, plums, molasses, brown sugar, and yeast. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with above average carbonation. The flavour is nutmeg/cinnamon, roasted malt, plums, yeast, and caramel. Love the flavour!
Very spicey. Very up front. In your face. Boozy. Caramel and toffee. A bit too rich. Not easy to drink. A sipping beer.

Bottle from LCBO. Aroma is mostly spice. Taste is sweet with dark malts, and surprise, tons of spice. This is standard Unibroue yeast spiciness, but amplified by the addition of extra spices, but still not over-the-top. Very enjoyable.

Nice different label-style painted on their typical big brown bottles. Pours an amber-red colour, hazy, with a big light-mocha coloured head, great retention and some thick foamy lace. Dark fruit aromas (prunes, dates, cherries) with caramel, nutty yeast and hints of mint. The caramel is more apparent in the taste with still minty hops. The dark fruits are covered by the yeast and some spices. Been a while since I had a good Unibroue like this one. Keep these coming !

33 cl bottle, Calgary, AB, Canada mixed 12 pack. Dark rose brown. Sweet prune clove aroma with a mint freshness. Sweet, major clove flabour with some faint berry in the background. Long (persistent) alcohol and raisin finsih.

Bottle, shared with Parksy, Grippitis, JJ. Dark brown, hazy, with a very lively beige head. Lovely spicy aroma and flavour, uniquely spicy-- floral ginger (galangal?), sweet aniseed, prunes, dark caramel... This is fantastic! It falls in line with many of the Trader Joe limited that Unibroue does, very complex, delicious.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Another great beer from unibroue. Pours dark brown with a hint of ruby, lots of frothy head and considerable lacing. Nose is sweet candy and brown bread. Flavours of ginger bread, dark fruit, some molasses. Taste med/heavy sweet light bitter. Full somewhat creamy body with medium carbonation.

On tap at the beer bistro, and in a 750ml corked and caged bottle from the lcbo. Dark brown, with a ruby hue, and a small off white head, soicy aroma, but very warming. Cinnamon, nutmeh, some cloves, with a rich bready malt base, with some cherries, and dark candied fruit. Soft, but bubbly carb, with a slightly viscous mouth feel. The finish is sweet, but not over powering, a light bitterness, with some more subtle fruitiness, and alot of warming spice. A nice xmas season sipper,

Rouge brique recouverte dune mosse volumineuse, laissant une écume traîner. Un nez dépices variées bien plaisant; muscade, vanille et un peu de clou de girofle. Des odeurs de paillais dautomne, de sous-bois et darbres sans feuilles. En bouche, les épices sont différentes. Cest lanis et le gingembre. Elle semble mince au début, mais se gonfle le torse ensuite. Agréable à boire. (1318-011114)

Bottle. Dark mahogany with tan head. Huge holiday spice...nutmeg, cloves, coriander, I think some cumin, yeast, singer caramel malt. High carbonation, sweet and holiday spice, moderate body, slightly dry. I think it needs more time to balance but good.

Boisson couleur cola, à mi-chemin entre le rouge sang et le brun chocolat ; couche de mousse couleur crème à la surface, et texture semi-épaisse. Le nez est passablement épicé, passant du clou de girofle à la cannelle, avec du rooibos et du thé du labrador pour compléter le tableau. La bouche est chaude, complexe, épicée bien sûr, rondement fruitée et dans lensemble délicieuse. Un brin trop pétillante, mais sinon elle est absolument charmante.
balanced, on sweet side. herbal tasted dark colour, medium plus mouthful. Decent though not expressional. .

Bottle 750ml. Thx Alex.
Pours black with medium-high beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of spices, malt, sugar. Taste is of spices, malt, sugar, alcohol. Palate: Over carbonated for the style imo. Medium-full bodied. Overall: Pretty good. Spicy, heavy, sweet.

Couleur brune foncé avec un col beige plus ou moins résistant. Liquide très complexe dépices comme la canelle,clou de giroffle,muscade,menthe, caramel, grains grillés, un peu de chocolat. Carbonation un peu trop élevé. Je ne suis pas fan de Unibroue mais une bonne bière malgré tout!

Pours a thick, dark brown. Aroma is yeast, bread dough, and toasted nuts. Taste is the first and foremost the typical spicy yeast profile youd expect of a Belgian ale, with hints of caramel, toffee, coffee and roasted nuts. Full, rich body. Soft carbonation. Very tasty.

Medium brown, thin head, little bit of redness. Aroma is floral, spicy, dates, coriander, brown malts and booze. Sweet and strong with a massive anise spice, followed by dulce de leche richness, complex herbal notes and a warming finish.
Poured from 750mL bottle. Medium-dark copper brown with beige head. Aroma of vegetable, gingerbread, christmas spices. Flavour same with Unibroue belgian yeast. Medium body.

Pours a dark brown with no head so no lacing. Nose is of cloves and coriander, caramel. Taste is fresh from the cloves and moderately bitter. Really spicy and some light dark fruits. Body is medium and carbonation is moderate. Overall a nice one, not that much of the Unibroue signature (a good thing).

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2015 Bière brune foncé aux reflets rubis, totalement embrouillée, très effervescente, et surmontée dun très large col beige, très dense et mousseux, bien persistant, et qui laisse une riche dentelle sur les parois du verre. Arômes de levure belge (typiquement Unibroue!) avec quelques épices (poivre et piment de la Jamaïque surtout peut-être un peu de clou de girofle et de muscade) et beaucoup de sucré (caramel, érable, mélasse, crème brûlée et même, cest un peu étonnant, caramel brûlé). Dailleurs, les effluves ont une tendance évidente vers laspect «brûlé» du malt torréfié (pain très grillé, grain brûlé). Par moment, des odeurs sapparentant à des esters de fermentation semblent percer, mais ça reste occulté par cet «effet brûlé» plus ou moins agréable rappelant un peu le gâteau aux épices oublié au four ou le caramel carbonisé au fond dun chaudron. Nez plus ou moins agréable donc, intensité moyenne, complexité intéressante. En bouche, pétillement moyen sur la langue, onctuosité intéressante au palais, le breuvage est moelleux et velouté, présentant une certaine rondeur. Au goût, levure Unibroue, pain très grillé, sucres (caramel, léger érable, mélasse, crème brûlée), mais on retrouve encore ce petit «effet brûlé» qui rappelle le gâteau trop cuit ou le caramel brûlé, même si cest moins pire quau nez. Aussi, beaucoup dépices en bouche, cest très chaud, poivre, piment de la Jamaïque, et peut-être aussi dautres piments forts considérant la grande chaleur qui envahit les joues et la gorge du dégustateur. On note également un petit goût herbacé (houblon ou épice tel que coriandre?) en arrière-plan. Lamertume est minimale, cette bière est principalement sucrée et épicée. En bouche, comme cétait le cas au nez, lintensité est moyenne, la complexité est intéressante. Ça reste une très bonne bière, mais sans ce petit «effet brûlé» un peu désagréable, elle aurait pu être excellente.

750 ml bottle from Broue Ha Ha, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.: Deep brown, murky?, with a decent ashen-tan head and good lacing.
 
Aroma: Quite sweet, malty and spicy, lots of clove, some ginger, cinnamon/allspice?, brown sugar, bubble gum esters, toffee, almost molasses, a little buttery, not exactly what Im wanting after all the wait from Unibroue.
 
Palate: Medium+ body, full, rounded effervescence.
 
Flav.: Much like the nose...quite rich, sweet, malty and spicy, plenty of clove and warm spices, brown sugar, toffee, more molasses than the nose; sweet with limited bitterness and a long, spicy, sweetly malty finish. 

Nicely done, though not what I would have preferred for such an ostentatious release!
Draft - Toasted malts, toffee and some spice. Deep brown with a rich light brown head. Malty and spicy with a rich palate. Nice, but only in smaller quantities.

A really solid brew. Pours out a dark almost black, opaque body with a splotchy, soapy off white head. The nose is spiced, yeasty, caramelized, mildly roasted and somewhat fruity. There is a nice prune and dried fruit taste in the middle. Nice toffee and nutty roasted malt character, bold Belgian spiced notes and full yeast notes. Tons of esters and coriander with a prune backbone. Overall a great, well balanced and slightly boozy finish.

Nouvelle Unibroue. De couleur obscure..Nez de cannelle,cardamome,poivre,pain dépice avec une aspect de beurre salé discret lové dun caramel onctueux..En bouche cest quand même pétillant une bonne touche de cerise,vanille , chocolat mais avec une bonne dose dépices en fin de bouche(anis,poivre,cloue de girofle) laissant une bonne chaleur en gorge.Très bonne bière de balcon pour lautomne-hiver.Taux dalcool honnête. Le seul défaut est ce goût de levure typique dUnibroue... mais bon la résolution est den racheter une autre aussitôt que je laperçois....

750ml bottle. Nice brownish thick head very well sustained. Very dark brown color. caramel notes and rosted malts smell , maybe melasse and a bit woody! Taste is Roasty , caramel ... feels like an alcohol ginger bread . the alcohol is not very well hidden but I dont think its a flaw here. Jerry Vietz sure knows how to brew!! nice one ! feels refreshing from what Unibroue is giving us in recent years
A nice Belgian ale. Pours a dark murky maroon. Lively and effervescent. Aromas of bubblegum and sweet dried fruit. Flavors are quite boozy and medicinal. Dried fruit, spices, and caramel. Good stuff.

Belle mousse beige comme une neige éternelle montée sur un liquide brun. Une dentelle qui décore le verre. Un nez franchement épicé (anis, clou, muscade et/ou autre chose de la même famille moléculaire) avec des parfums de caramel, de banane en panure, de biscuit de Noël et de biscuit Pattes dours à la mélasse. Un goût désagréablement épicé et malté avec un alcool qui naide pas: gingembre, clou, anis, cannelle, toffee, cassonade, muscade et autres affaires qui agressent mes papilles. En bouche, un liquide qui nest pas différent des autres produits de la maison. En finale, un alcool chaud qui souligne chaque trait épicé et un sucre résiduel qui se gonfle à chaque gorgée. Dans la lignée de la Réserve de Noël des Trois Mousquetaires : trop sucrée, trop épicée, trop chaude, difficile à boire et trop dispendieuse. Cest mon humble avis. Vous en faites ce que vous voulez. Vous nêtes pas heureux? Et bien moi aussi figurez-vous.

Muddy mahogany pour with off white head. Aroma comes across tart with prunes and dark fruits. Flavour has caramel, toffee, rich dark fruits and a very spicy yeasty finish. Alcohol is hidden incredibly well and is remarkably light bodied for 10%. A bit much for my tastes.
Bottle from MLCC. Pours very dark with minimal head that dissipates quickly. Tasted quite sour. Somewhat metallic. Not my fave.
Bottle. Dark brown pour, small beige head. Some savory spice notes, soy sauce bordering on teriyaki, with some gingerbread and other Christmas spices. A bit of a disappointment.

A big surprise to see a new Unibroue on the shelf. Dark brown with a thick lasting soft foam head. Aroma of dark spice reminiscent of Christmas pudding. Taste of light bodied dark malt, Christmas spices and toast. Growing alcohol warmth

Des effluves de vanille, dalcool et de caramel au beurre nous atteignent dès le départ. Ça goûte sucré, caramélisé, avec un léger soupçon de bourbon en finale. Les épices sont là et justement dosées, cest bien équilibré et ça valait lattente (depuis leur dernière nouveauté). À laveugle, un amateur reconnaîtra tout de suite la touche caractéristique dUnibroue; jaurais apprécié être un peu challengé là-dessus, avec un peu plus daudace de la part du brasseur... Excellente bière, voilà tout!
Brune très foncé. Opaque. Mousse blanche. Très épicé. Caramel. Cannelle. Muscade. Boisé. Gingembre. Réglisse. Fine chaleur dalcool. Levure. Une explosion dépice. Excellente.

Un nez de noël; pain dépices, gâteau aux fruits, cannelle, vanille etc. Un nez puissant, persistant et épicé.
Le visuel est brun foncé aux reflets roux, à la mousse légèrement effervescente et au maintient selon la moyenne. Quelques traces apparaissent sur le verre. 
Au gustatif, leffervescence et la chaleur dalcool composent lattaque à prime abord. Les épices sont très en évidence avec des notes de pain dépices, de gâteau aux fruits, de cannelle etc. Leffervescence très active, combinée aux notes dépices, rendent cette bière pétillante et vive. Signature Unibroue reconnue cependant. Agréable à boire sans être un grand cru. Pour le temps des fêtes a coup sur.
Large frothy yellowish rad atop of a deep brownish body. Nose of Christmas cake, spearmint toothpaste. Pretty deep plums, cloves and spice. Not terrible depth but brings me back to Edition 2005.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2014 Bouteille 750 ml. 10%. Brune très foncée, presque noire, mousse beige. Arôme dépices (cardamome, girofle), de fruits, de levures. En bouche grande effervescence, notes dépices, porto, un peu danis étoilée, caramel, raisins secs. Finale avec une certaine amertume dépices. Bonne.

on tap at ninkasi, qc. dark brown-burgundy with a healthy light beige head offering good retention and lacing. cinnamon, cloves, cardamom and cherry meat, cranberries and other spices, roasted caramel sweetness, astringent woodsy notes, perfumey and flowery alcohol - lavender mostly, sweetness - lightly sweetened dried cranberries, maple syrup touch, nice belgian yeast - unibroues classic yeast strain is probably overshadowed by powerful spices but clearly produces lots of fruity and peppery spicy esters. bright to average carbonation, light to medium body, very spicy and lightly astringent finish. much enjoyed!

On tap. Pours dark brown with moderate head. Aromas of mixed Christmas spices, dark raisins, and roasted malts. Flavors of dark Christmas cake with lots of nutmeg, cinnamon and ginger; dark fruit, vanilla and licorice. Strong flavors. Nice.

750 ml from local metro grocery A: spicy : cardamom, nutmeg, cinnamon. Dark caramel, light roastiness, cherry. App: dark brown thick beige head and good lacing. T/p: full body with initial sweet but finishes on a good bitter note. Moderate high carbonation. O: a nice surprise. The spiciness is interesting well upfront and lasting. could have benefit more roundness. I will definitely stack some more.

Aroma:dark fruit,cherry, caramel light spicy and yeast...
Appearance:Dark redish brown,good head...
Flavor:Dark fruit,cherry caramel, light spicy...

Draught at St. Augustines, VancouverDark brown color with compact head. The aroma is mild, a bit vegetable and spicy. Good body strength, round mouthfeel, the flavor is basically caramel, with some fruity esters and mild spicy component. Correct bitterness.Not a big fan of spiced beers, but its well brewed anyway.

Bouteille - 750ml. Corps brun foncé avec effervescence moyenne. La mousse beige pale est dépaisseur moyenne mais sétiole rapidement. Arome riche et complexe dans lequel on décèle des nuances de baies sauvages, de caramel, dépices et de levures belges typiques dUnibroue. Lalcool reste très subtil. Son goût malté/houblonné est puissant mais bien équilibré. On peut apprécier des notes fuitées, sucrées, boisées et liquoreuses. Belle finale longue et réconfortante. Ça faisait longtemps que Unibroue avait cessé de créer de nouveaux produits. Jespère que ceci est le début dun regain de créativité fructueux et aux antipodes de la malheureuse tentative de percer le marché des bières désinvoltes il y a environ dix ans. Je prends la résolution den mettre une en réserve jusquau Nouvel an!

A very nice dark ale to start off the soon winter season. Notes of ginger bread, dark fruits like prunes, burnt caramel. It has it all. Reminiscent to Unibroue 17 for me, but lacks the notes of aging/oak that U17 presents - but well worth the money.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2014 Arôme de caramel, dalcool & dépices sur une belle robe couleur sirop dérable. Jai trouvé son gout de levure belge plutôt simple, malgré les épices, sur une finale en bouche vraiment top de biscuits caramélisés et de toffee. Autrement dit: tout pour la finale. Excellente bière de nouelle  ahah! :))

Noire opaque aux rares reflets rubis, coiffée dune épaisse mousse couleur crème. Leffervescence est vigoureuse et incessante. Au nez, un bouquet dépices se dégage sur une trame de levures belges. En bouche, la mousse goûte le caramel doux. Lorsquon rejoint enfin la bière, on pense dabord à une vague impression de cerise noire avant que les épices se mettent de la partie. On parle dun pain dépice sur la bouteille et on ne nous ment pas. Je goûte de lanis, de la muscade, de la cardamome, du gingembre, de la cannelle avec une finale poivrée qui se mêle à la chaleur de lalcool. À travers le tout, des notes dérable et de café fraîchement moulu sont perceptibles. Le sucre résiduel est bien dosé; il enrobe lensemble sans alourdir la dégustation (mais ça demeure une grosse bière assez lourde, ne le cachons pas). Cest excellent. Je ferai des réserves pour les fêtes.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. Deep floral aroma. Tastes rich, delicate, perfume-y. Deep brunette body. Nice head. To me the beer tastes like falling in love. Gorgeous. Fin.

Kind of thin body, but dark with a white soapy head and some lacing, not much head retention. Aroma of dried fruit, banana, grapes, cola and coconut. Taste is like a typical belgian ale with a touch of holiday spice, touches of pumpkin even. A touch of pepper in the aftertaste. Very vibrant tingly palate. Unique beer but still within the realm of Unibroues style. Abv very well masked, you dont get any sense this is a 10% beer. Quite nice.

Apparence: D?une couleur brun très foncé opaque, elle est coiffée d?une mousse généreuse d?une bonne durée. Effervescence difficile à évaluer, mais semble quasi inexistante. 

Arômes: Au nez, ce sont des arômes de malt caramélisé et dépices.

bouteille de 341 ml de brune avec mousse crémeuse. Au nez arômes floral, muscade malt torréfié, une fois que la mousse se dissipe on a des notes marqué de caramel. Au goût on a une acidité bien présente, des notes de caramel aussi bien présente et des notes de fer. Le sucré et lacidité séquilibre bien. En fin de gorgée on a une chaleur marqué par un taux élevé dalcool. Bonne bière dautomne/ hiver.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2014 *** Re-Rate... (à noter que la deuxième fois où jai bu cette bière, la mousse était généreuse et tenace... Sans doute suis-je tombé sur une mauvaise bouteille la première fois...) 
Bière de couleur brun foncé, dont la mousse est dabord généreuse, mais ensuite très fugace : il faudra brasser le liquide dans le verre pour la voire apparaitre de nouveau. Nez de réglisse rouge, dépices. Rien dexceptionnel. On dénote la présence des levures typiques dUnibroue. En bouche, cest puissant : notes de réglisse encore une fois, de fruits rouges, de mûres, de bleuets. Capiteuse, cette bière me semble sapprocher du style Abt ou quadruple. Javais espéré quelque chose de plus différent. On reste, il faut le dire, dans la lignée de la Réserve 17, de la Terrible, etc. Ça goûte la Unibroue, ce qui nest bien sûr pas un défaut, mais pour la moitié du prix, jaime autant prendre une bonne petite Trois-Pistoles. Cheers!

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2014 Une bouteille de 750ml avec bouchon de liège. Une vrai bière brune avec une mousse durable, forte teneur en gaz carbonique. Un nez épicé, de lanis. Une bouche aussi à lanis, du pain dépice. Facile et drôlement légère pour sa teneur en alcool.

750mL bottle, pours a deep dark brown with a medium, quickly-dissipating beige head. Aroma is very complex, full of Belgian yeasts, spices a la gingerbread, and very light toffee. Flavour is extremely complex and amazingly well-rounded, with notes of toffee, gingerbread spice, and complex Belgian yeasts. Wow -- this is one of the most complex Unibroue beers out there. High carbonation allows all the flavours to shine. Phenomenal stuff.

750ml bottle pours black in color with a 2 finger white head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel and licorice with some light roasted notes and hints of spice. Taste is licorice with a ccaramel malty sweetness and a spicy hop bitterness. Medium bodied with abundant carbonation leaving a pleasant sensation on the palate. A nicely crafted brew that is tasty and well balanced.
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2014 Light body for the abv. Smooth and toasty, with mild gingerbread spiciness.  Typical unibroue yeast profile. A fine beer with subdued spice.
